questions.text: What is liver disease's most common and characteristic symptom?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fatigue Fatigue is the most common and most characteristic sy mptom of liver disease. It is described as lethargy, weakness, listlessness, malaise, increased need for sleep, lack of stamina, and poor energy. The fatigue of liver disease typically arises after activity or exercise and is rarely present or severe after adequate rest; that is, it is “afternoon” rather than “morning” fatigue.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Nausea occurs with more severe liver disease and may accompany fatigue and can be provoked by smelling food odors or eating fatty foods. Vomiting can occur but is rarely persistent or prominent. Option: B: Poor appetite with weight loss frequently occurs in acute liver disease but is rare in chronic disease except when cirrhosis is present and advanced. Option: D: Jaundice is the hallmark symptom of liver disease and perhaps the most reliable marker of severity. Symptoms of liver cirrhosis R Nose bleeding/bleeding from lower limbs Anorexia/weight loss The feeling of an enlarged abdomen Jaundice/itch Swollen abdomen/legs Hand tremors Physical findings ● Skin pigmentation ● Xanthoma ● Spider angioma ● Palmar erythema ● Finger clubbing (hepatopulmonary syndrome) ● Caput medusae ● Gynecomastia ● Fever ● Hepatoceleoma ● Hepatic halitosis (dimethyl-sulfide, ketones in the expired breath) ● Jaundice ● Ascites, lower thigh edema ● Hepatic encephalopathy ● Bleeding plaque/purpura

questions.text: What is the most frequently reported upper limit of normal for conjugated bilirubin?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

0.3 mg/dL Normal total serum bilirubin values are reported between 1 and 1.5 mg/dL, with 95% of a normal population falling between 0.2 and 0.9 mg/dL. If the direct-acting fraction is < 15% of the total, the bilirubin can be considered as only indirect. The most frequently reported upper limit of normal for conjugated bilirubin is 0.3 mg/dL. Option: D: Clinical jaundice is evident on the sclera.

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for liver injury. Which of the following is a more specific indicator of liver injury?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) ALT is found primarily in the liver and is a more specific indicator of liver injury. The aminotransferases are generally present in the serum in low concentrations. These enzymes are released more significantly into the blood when damage to the liver cell membrane increases permeability. Liver cell necrosis is not required to release the aminotransferases, and there is a poor correlation between the degree of liver cell damage and the level of the aminotransferases. Thus, the absolute elevation of the aminotransferases is of no prognostic significance in acute hepatocellular disorders.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: AST is found in the liver, cardiac muscle, skeletal muscle, kidneys, brain, pancreas, lungs, leukocytes, and erythrocytes in decreasing order of concentration. Option: C, D: Activities of three enzymes— alkaline phosphatase, 5′-nucleotidase , and γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)—are usually elevated in cholestasis. Liver Function Tests (LFTs) AST (aspartate aminotransferase) (11-47 IU/L) AST is an enzyme found throughout the body, but predominantly in heart and liver cells. Most useful in detecting liver damage due to hepatitis, drugs toxic to the liver, cirrhosis, and alcoholism. Often ordered in conjunction with ALT. ALT (alanine aminotransferase) (7-56 IU/L) An enzyme found mostly in the cells of the liver and kidney. When the liver is damaged, ALT is released into the blood stream. ALT is a useful test for detecting liver damage. Most useful in detecting damage due to hepatitis and drugs or other substances toxic to the liver. Often ordered in conjunction with AST. AST/ALT Ratio The AST/ALT ratio is usually increased in alcoholic hepatitis, cirrhosis, and in the first day or two of acute hepatitis or injury from bile duct obstruction. ALP (alkaline phosphatase) (30-120 IU/L) Found in bone and in the cells of bile ducts. ALP can indicate blockage of one or more bile ducts, liver cancer, hepatitis, cirrhosis, or when hepatotoxic drugs are taken.

AST<300, BUT AST/ALT>2 Suggests ALD.Ratio>3 is highly suggestive of ALD Alcohol+toxin intake raises AST and ALT, but the ratio is maintained. In cirrhosis -there is less clearance of AST.AST is more than ALT. Conditions in which AST is specific for the liver– .Alcohol, alcohol+Toxin, cirrhosis

questions.text: Which of the following LFT report is highly suggestive of alcoholic liver disease?
questions.correct_answer: C. AST: 280 IU/L and ALT: 70 IU/L
questions.explanation:
Solution:

AST: 280 IU/L and ALT: 70 IU/L An AST: ALT ratio > 2:1 is suggestive, whereas a balance> 3:1 is highly suggestive of alcoholic liver disease . The AST in alcoholic liver disease is rarely > 300 IU/L, and the ALT is often expected. A low level of ALT in the serum is due to an alcohol-induced pyridoxal phosphate deficiency. Alcohol is thought to cause injury to the mitochondria, which contain AST but not ALT. In addition, in chronic alcoholics, pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency may reduce the synthesis of ALT more than AST because the former is more B6-dependent. Extra Edge – AST Is present in Mitochondria>Cytosol. Liver>heart>Muscle>kidney>brain>pancreas ALT – Present in Cytosol Liver >other tissues

questions.text: A patient can have an elevation of serum alkaline phosphatase after eating a fatty meal. His blood group is most likely:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B Alkaline phosphate is produced from the canalicular membrane of hepatocytes. The normal Range is 40-140 IU/L. The elderly have mildly elevated alkaline phosphatase (1–1.5 times normal). In contrast, individuals with blood types O and B can have an elevation of serum alkaline phosphatase after eating a fatty meal due to the influx of intestinal alkaline phosphatase into the blood. pregnancy, it is high due to the influx of placental alkaline phosphatase. If an elevated serum alkaline phosphatase is the only abnormal finding in a healthy person, or if the degree of elevation is higher than expected in the clinical setting, identifying the source of elevated isoenzymes is helpful. This problem can be approached in two ways. The first and most precise is the fractionation of the alkaline phosphatase by electrophoresis . The second, best substantiated, and most available approach involves the measurement of serum 5′-nucleotidase or GGT. These enzymes are rarely elevated in conditions other than liver disease.

questions.text: A study is being done for acute measurement of synthetic hepatic function and wants to set its parameters. Which of the following products of the liver has the shortest half-life?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Factor VII Clotting factor serum half-lives are much shorter than albumin, ranging from 6 h for factor VII to 5 days for fibrinogen. Because of their rapid turnover, measurement of the clotting factors is the single best acute measure of synthetic hepatic function . It helps diagnose and assess the prognosis of acute parenchymal liver disease.

questions.text: 15-year-old male showed on a routine investigation unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Stool and urine color was standard. The urine routine shows no bilirubin. There was no evidence of hemolysis, and the liver function test was otherwise standard. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gilbert syndrome Unconjugated Hyperbilirubinemia. Autosomal Recessive. It is due to the reduced activity of uridine diphosphate glucuronyl transferase. The activity of UGT1A1 is reduced to 30%of normal. It is a benign asymptomatic hereditary jaundice, often detected by routine checkups or mild jaundice. Male preponderance.Bilirubin levels generally <3 mg/dl. Fasting, illness, alcohol, stress -bilirubin rises and returns to normal. No treatment is required. Crigler Najjar Syndrome - Autosomal Recessive inheritance Type 1 –. severe indirect hyperbilirubinemia. Complete inactivity of uridine diphosphate glucuronyl transferase . They are at risk of developing The definitive treatment is Liver transplantation. Type 2 –The enzyme level is low. <10%of normal.No kernicterus Dubin Johnson– Autosomal Recessive. mostly in Adolescents. Conjugated Hyperbilirubinemia is due to the reduced excretory function of hepatocytes( MRP2 defective ). Liver biopsy shows centrilobular black pigment(pigmentation due to epinephrine) Rotor syndrome Defect in OATP b1/b3.reduced reuptake of bilirubin conjugates Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with an excellent prognosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented with pruritus, light-colored stools, and high-colored urine. A liver function test revealed raised alkaline phosphatase. The tests to differentiate ALP Increase due to liver or from others are all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aspartate aminotransferase The clinical scenario suggests cholestatic liver disease. Alkaline phosphatase is not specific to the liver. Elevations are more significant than four times the They are seen in patients with cholestatic liver disorders, infiltrative liver diseases such as cancer and amyloidosis, and bone conditions such as Paget's disease. Tests that help differentiate liver disease from others are fractionating the alkaline phosphatase by electrophoresis, serum 5′-nucleotidase, or GGT.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: GGT is a microsomal enzyme induced by phenytoin, warfarin, and rifampicin . it increases in parallel with ALP. If ALP is normal, increased GGT signifies alcohol consumption. GGT is located in the endoplasmic reticulum and bile duct epithelial cells. Reflecting its more diffuse localization in the liver, GGT elevation in serum is less specific for cholestasis than alkaline phosphatase or five ′- nucleotidase elevations . Option B: 5′-nucleotidase is found in or near the bile canalicular membrane of hepatocytes; it is used to differentiate the rise of ALP due to liver or other causes. It is raised in obstructive jaundice, hepatic metastasis, and parenchymal liver disease. Option D: The first and most precise is the fractionation of the alkaline phosphatase by electrophoresis.
